intro: Solanum quercifolium, commonly known as the oak-leaf nightshade, is a perennial shrub native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its large, lobed, oak-like leaves and produces clusters of violet to purple flowers. The plant bears small, round berries that turn from green to yellow or red as they mature. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is often found in arid or semi-arid environments. Solanum quercifolium is part of the nightshade family (Solanaceae) and contains toxic compounds, making it potentially harmful to livestock and humans.
